this depends on the particular skills business types with no open source experience are often terrible when they are in a position of authority over open source developers the profit model is entirely different and apparently incomprehensible unless they ve either seen it up close or have very carefully studied e g cygnus and rhat business models

i spent a few years in the mid is working on the design of fault tolerant organizations hoping to create information exchange pathways inside organizations that limited the harm that could be done through the loss or failure of any individual the large scale experiment the scaleable company that we were building pretty much failed ended up being rebuilt form the ground up on a different basis using contractor labor in part because i had neither identified nor solved these problems and in part because we were working inside an existing organizational structure and not all the systems for necessary decentralization and elimination of single points of failure could be implemented as much as the article is text the image you chose to illustrate it speaks to the most interesting approach to this problem i have seen anyone take to date about years ago a good friend was running a nonprofit with a chronically dysfunctional board of directors he gained access to a big pulling boat or big oars on a lifeboat sized wooden hull i think it was a replica of one of the launches on capt vancouver is ship and he took the board out for a spin and steered them into serious currents way out in the bay and then disabled the rudder at which point they really had no choice other than a tow from the coast guard but to cooperate at a truly physical level to listen with their arms and backs and legs to one another is muscles on the other oars and coordinate their efforts if they were to get back to the harbor but whether or not a single experience like that can really change the way people deal with one another is another matter entirely
